title: Determining Bile Duct Density in the Mouse Liver
procedures:
All animals were housed in a barrier animal facility at Baylor College of Medicine per Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee guidelines and under approved animal protocols.
1. Collection of Mouse Liver Tissue
Preparation of mouse for liver harvest
Euthanize the mouse using isoflurane.
Perform cervical dislocation of the mouse to ensure death.
Make a transverse incision approximately one inch below the rib cage.
Expose the entire ventral surface of the liver.
Collection of the mouse liver
Carefully, with small scissors, cut through the ligaments connecting the liver to other organs in the abdomen.
Cut through the common BD to detach the liver from the intestine.
Carefully remove the liver by holding onto the gallbladder and immediately place in a 50 mL tube filled to three-quarters by 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA).
2. Fixation and Embedding the Liver in Paraffin
Fixation
Fix the liver tissue for 48 h in 4% PFA at 4 °C.
Wash the tissue with 70% EtOH for 1 h at 4 °C.
Wash the tissue twice with 95% EtOH for 1 h each at 4 °C.
Wash the tissue twice with 100% EtOH for 1 h each at 4 °C.
Clearing
Wash the liver tissue with clearing agent (Table of Materials) three times for 30 min each at room temperature.
NOTE: The liver should feel rigid following the third wash.
Embedding in paraffin
Place the tissue cassette in a tissue mold in paraffin wax for 3 washes, 30 min each. Wax should be preheated to 60 °C.
Fill the tissue mold with paraffin wax to three-quarters height and keep on a heating block at 60 °C.
Place the liver in the mold with the ventral side facing up.
Carefully remove the mold from the heating block.

Place the top of the cassette on the mold and top off with hot liquid paraffin.
Allow the mold and block to cool to room temperature overnight.
NOTE: Tissue blocks can now be stored at room temperature.
3. Sectioning liver tissue
Preparation of the block for sectioning
Place the mold on ice for 5 min before removing the block from the mold.
Place the block on ice with a lab tissue paper present between block and ice.
Keep the block on ice when not sectioning for best tissue slicing results.
Sectioning the liver blocks
Using a microtome, begin by sectioning through the superficial, dorsal side of the liver. Sections should be 5 µm.
Check the superficial sections under a dissection microscope to ensure sections are not sheared or folded.
Take a section of the liver that includes the caudate lobe.
NOTE: For some blocks, you will have the left, medial, right and caudate lobes on the same tissue slice.
For those blocks where all four lobes are not present on the same slide, continue to slice until the left, medial and right lobes are present on the same slide.
4. Immunohistochemistry for wsCK and αSMA
Processing of slides for immunohistochemistry
Select one slide per genotype to be analyzed.
Wash the slide for 15 min in Xylene, 100% EtOH, 95% EtOH and finally 70% EtOH (3 x 5 min in each solution).
Wash the slide for 5 min in deionized H2O.
Immerse the slide in the antigen retrieval solution (Tris-based, high pH).
Heat under pressure in a pressure cooker for 3 min at 10 psi.
Allow the slide to cool to room temperature (approximately 35 min).
Blocking the tissue sections
Using a Pap Pen, outline the sections on the slide.

Apply phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) + 0.1% Tween to cover the section twice, 5 min each.
Make blocking buffer by mixing Normal Goat Serum (NGS) at 1:50 in PBS + 0.3% Triton. To have enough buffer for both blocking and primary antibody application, 100 µL per section is sufficient.
Apply 100 µL of blocking solution per section.
Incubate the slides covered with the blocking solution at 4 °C for 1 h.
Staining for wsCK and αSMA 
Dilute anti-CK8 and anti-CK19 antibodies16 (Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank, TROMA-I and TROMA-III, respectively) 1:20 in blocking buffer to stain for wsCK. Dilute the anti-αSMA antibody17 (Table of Materials) to 1:200 in the same buffer.
Apply 100 µL of the diluted antibody solution containing all three antibodies to each section.
Incubate the slides covered with the antibody solution at 4 °C overnight.
Wash the slides with PBS + 0.1% Triton three times, 5 min each.
Dilute secondary antibodies (anti-rat-Alexa488 and anti-mouse-Cy5) 1:200 in PBS + 0.3% Triton.
Apply 100 µL of the secondary antibody solution containing both secondary antibodies to the slides.
Incubate at room temperature for 1 h.
DAPI nuclear staining and mounting
Wash the slides three times, 5 min each.
Apply 100 µL of DAPI (1:3000) to each section for 10 min.
Apply Antifade Mounting Medium (Table of Materials) to the slides and place a glass coverslip on top of the tissue sections. Leave the slides at 4 °C overnight. Seal the slides the next day.
Store the slides at 4 °C and image within 1 week of mounting.
5. Imaging and Quantification of BDs
Imaging liver sections
Prior to imaging, blind yourself to the genotype of the sample with help from a lab member. Ensure all imaging files are devoid of genotype or other specific identifying information besides an animal/sample number.

Using a fluorescent microscope, take 20x images at 1x zoom of each section and ensure that every PV across the liver is imaged. Include the left, medial, right and caudate lobes.
NOTE: We usually find 60-90 portal tracts per animal depending on the size of the liver.
To identity the PVs, look for αSMA plus wsCK staining. Structures that are αSMA positive but lack wsCK staining are not portal structures.
Identification and counting of BDs
Create a spreadsheet with the following columns: Animal/Sample Number, Image Number, Number of PVs, and Number of BDs.
Going through each image, identify and record the number of PVs per image.
Identify patent BDs in each image by the presence of cholangiocytes (wsCK+) surrounding a definable lumen. Structures should be distinct and separated by mesenchyme from other wsCK+ cells.
Count each patent BD and place in the same column as the image number.
Do this for each image taken of a PV.
Calculate the sum of all PVs and all BDs in the liver sample.
Calculate the BD to PV ratio for the liver sample.
